awd_titl_txt: Guided Ion Beam and Computational Studies of Singlet Oxygen Reactions With Guanine Radical Cations in Nucleobases, Nucleosides, and Their Native and Mismatched Base Pairs
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jianbo Liu and his students at the Queens College of the City University of New York (CUNY) is using combined experimental and theoretical approaches to study the chemical reaction of guanine radical cations with a reactive oxygen species called singlet oxygen. Guanine is one of the four nucleobases of RNA (ribonucleic acid) and DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid).  It is normally a neutral molecule with all electrons paired, but when one electron is removed, it becomes what is called a radical cation.  The radical form of a molecule is often more chemically reactive than its neutral form.  Professor Liu and his research team are exploring the reaction of guanine radical cation and singlet oxygen, as this reaction provides insight into how living systems deal with damage to DNA and RNA, for example, from ultraviolet light exposure (sunburn).  This research project may also advance photodynamic therapies for cancer treatments.  This project is providing training for two doctoral and three Master's students each year.  Professor Liu participates in Undergraduate Research Mentoring, Federal Work-Study and MARC-U*STAR Programs to recruit undergraduate research students.  He also collaborates with CUNY Community College to integrate the community college faculty and students into his research program.

The project uses electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry and guided ion beam to probe singlet oxygen reactions and C8-hydroxylation of the radical cations of guanine, guanosine, 8-oxoguanine and their base pairs, in the order of increasing structural complexity. Radical cations are produced by in-source dissociation of copper-guanine complexes and singlet oxygen is generated using a chemical source without other reactive oxygen contaminants. Different aspects of reaction mechanisms are examined, these include: collision energy dependence and exothermic/endothermic product channels.  Also examined are the effects of base-pairing and mispairing, intra-base-pair proton transfer, non-Aufbau Singly Occupied Molecular Orbital (SOMO)-to-Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO) level switching, and explicitly hydrogen-bonded water ligands. Experiments are complemented by electronic structure calculations, Rice?Ramsperger?Kassel?Marcus (RRKM) modeling and direct dynamics simulations. One research thrust is to explore and benchmark reliable theoretical methods for tackling the unique reaction systems of doublet-state radical cations with electronically excited singlet oxygen of mixed open- and closed-shell characters. The students involved in this research are gaining valuable experience not only in the science of nucleobase-singlet oxygen reaction dynamics, but in instrument design and construction, and computational modeling (e.g., reaction kinetics, dynamics and ion trajectory simulations).  Many of the instruments developed for the research are also used in undergraduate laboratory courses.  Queens College is a Minority Serving Institution, with 40% of students being the first in their families to attend college.  The education and training aspects of this research project have direct implications for increasing diversity and broadening participation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Guanine has the lowest oxidation and ionization potential among the DNA components. This leads to facile formation of guanine radical cations upon ionization and one-electron oxidation of DNA, followed by secondary reactions of the ensuing guanine radical cations with oxidants which are produced in living organisms including singlet oxygen (one of the important reactive oxygen species). In fact, guanine and its oxidized derivative 8-oxoguanine are the two exclusive DNA targets for singlet oxygen. The singlet oxygen-induced oxidative damage of guanine and 8-oxoguanine results in mutagenesis, carcinogenesis, apoptosis, etc.

In this project, great strides were made in delineating reaction mechanisms, kinetics, and dynamics of guanine and 8-oxoguanine radical cations (and their conjugated neutral radicals) with singlet oxygen. We measured the singlet oxygenation of the radical cations of monomeric guanine and 8-oxoguanine nucleobases and nucleosides and their derivatives in the gas-phase rarefied environment using an electrospray ionization guided-ion beam mass spectrometer, wherein intrinsic reactivities of radical cations were examined in the absence of solvent. Measurements were carried out on the effects of kinetic energy, reactant hydration, and modifications of base structure on reaction overcomes. Singlet oxygenation of guanine radical cations leads to 8-peroxide as the initial product; while that of 8-oxoguanine radical cations presents a higher efficiency and leads to the formation of 5-peroxide.

After delineating intrinsic reactivities of monomeric guanine and 8-oxoguanine radical cations, we proceeded to investigate singlet oxygenation of a Waston-Crick base pair consisting of guanine (or 8-oxoguanine) and its complementary cytosine base. The intriguing dynamics of base-pair radical cations concerns intra-base pair proton transfer, which results in both radical cation of guanine (or 8-oxoguanine) and its neutral conjugated radical in the base-pair reaction. To deconvolute the mixed results in the experiment, theoretical modeling was utilized to differentiate the reactions of radical cations and neutral radicals. The experimental and computational findings revealed structural context effects in reaction pathways, reactivity, electrostatic effect, product stabilities, and base-pair strength. Among these, the most pronounced is that intra-base pair proton transfer enhances singlet oxygenation of the base pair.

Viewing that the oxidation of base-pair radical cations strongly depends on intra-base pair proton transfer, we were motivated to examine proton transfer kinetics by using collision-induced dissociation, as the dissociation products could distinguish the proton-transferred versus the conventional base-pair structures. An interesting finding is that dissociation product ions were dominated by the fragments generated from a proton-transferred base-pair structure, regardless of its relative energy versus the conventional structure. Furthermore, dissociation product distributions are completely against any statistical reaction mechanisms. These findings strengthened our hypothesis that non-statistical dissociation is characteristic of Watson-Crick base-pair ions. The finding adds to the work focusing on ionization and oxidatively generated damage in both native and mismatched base pairs, and implies the influence of base-pair tautomerization and opening on DNA spontaneous point mutations.

These works were published in 12 peer reviewed articles and 8 conference presentations. The results not only help understand the fundamental guanine radical oxidation chemistry but also imply additive effects that would be anticipated in combining ionizing radiation-based radiotherapy and singlet oxygen-based photodynamic therapy for cancers. The research also developed new computational approaches for modeling multireferential reaction potential energy surfaces.

The broader impacts of this project are reflected in the fact that Queens College of the City University of New York is a Minority Serving Institution. Our students represent a wide range of backgrounds, with more than 40% come from under-represented groups in science. Specifically, this project provided resources for four doctoral graduate students by supporting their dissertation research, one Master?s graduate student who later joined the Ph.D. program, and seven undergraduate research students. Most participants were female and minority. The research experiences shaped students career trajectories, and most students have moved on to graduate school, dental school, and physician assistance program.

The project has strengthened the collaboration with LaGuardia Community College to integrate the community college faculty and students into the research community, and enhanced the transfer of the community college students from an associated degree to a bachelor?s degree program. The project helped other educational activities, including the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation, the bridge program for transfer of students from CUNY community colleges to senior colleges, annual Gracia Science Laboratory Open House to local high school students and science teachers, and NYC and NYS science fairs.
